text: I took a step forward, keeping my voice as calm as I could.
“My friends, let me buy the drinks. There’s no need for anger.”
The drunkard glared at me and shoved me aside. Wine splashed across the floor, and his fist slammed onto the counter with a dull crack of wood.
“Don’t act like you’re some saint!”
“Everyone in this damn town looks down on me, don’t they?!”
I stumbled back as glass cups fell from the shelves, shattering with a sharp echo through the silent tavern.
His eyes burned with drunken rage, wild and lost—like a trapped beast lashing out at its cage.
I raised a hand, about to speak again, when the wind outside suddenly howled louder. The door slammed open with a heavy bang.
The fire in the hearth flickered low under the gust, its light trembling violently in the air. Everyone held their breath.
Cold air swept in from the doorway, carrying with it snow and the faint scent of steel.
The cloaked woman’s gaze fell upon the drunkard—calm, yet sharper than the winter wind.
“Looks like I came just in time. Are mornings here always this noisy?”
Her voice was clear and steady, without force, yet it carried an authority that silenced the room.
The drunk opened his mouth to curse, but it was as if an invisible hand had seized his throat. The air itself froze still.
My chest tightened. The fire flared back to life, and in its glow, her silver hair shimmered like the gleam of a blade.
She lifted a finger and flicked it lightly. The bottle in her hand spun gracefully, the spilled wine hanging midair as glimmering mist in the firelight.
Everything fell silent. Even the drunk himself froze, his fury suddenly drained away.
For a heartbeat, I realized—the entire tavern had gone still. Even the flames had ceased to sway.
“That’s enough.”
The drunk’s Adam’s apple bobbed. His lips trembled, but no sound came out. He staggered back, nearly losing his footing.
“Damn... crazy woman...”
He panted, muttering curses under his breath, then shoved the door open and stumbled into the snowstorm outside.
The door slammed shut behind him. A swirl of snow drifted in the fading wind, and silence returned to the tavern.
I took a deep breath, my chest still burning. Her gaze swept over me—no reproach in her eyes, only a faint, fleeting trace of pity.
I opened my mouth, but no words came. The fire danced once more, and its light shimmered in her eyes like a deep, frozen lake of snow.
